turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: --Lloyd Anderson, Petitioner, versus Alabama.
Mr. Greenberg, had you concluded your opening argument?
Mr. Clark, you may proceed.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Thank you, sir.
May it please the Court.
Mr.Greenberg yesterday afternoon gave his summary of the case which he substantially covered the facts.
However, I noted few discrepancies which I would like to call to the attention of the Court before I proceed with my argument.
There were some mention of some perspective jurors not being found and that they were Negroes, there is nothing in the record which shows whether they were whites or Negroes.
In fact, it appears that all five Negroes were called at this jury -- on this jury.
And while I'm mentioning that exhibit, I should like to point out that they're excused and they're not found and the members who were struck were all marked in red ink.
There's no discrimination as to whether they were not found or excused.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.
There is not, sir.
All the cards contained and they're all white cards.
They have the man's name, his occupation and where he lives.
There is nothing that would indicate his race, color or creed.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: May it please the Court.

My only information on that is Fikes versus State, in which they said that in the old jury roll was urged, there was a new one which contained approximately 1500 names of which 250 or 300 were Negroes.
That is my only information on that, Your Honor.

I should like to point out in the record on page 61 that if the hearing on these motions that the attorney for the petitioner made no objection except to the -- the number of Negroes on the jury roll.

Now, the Court, speaking to Attorney Gray says, "Do you make any claim in either of the grounds that there had been an arbitrary conduct in this Court as far as this venire is concerned that arbitrarily excluded any Negro that might be on this venire observance in this -- on this jury?"
And Attorney Hall says, "No, sir."
"Further, as I understand you just simply say that you don't think there were enough Negroes in the jury box or some reason connected with the jury roll or jury box."
Attorney Hall says, "Yes, sir."
That's on record page 71.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: 61, sir, I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: What was meant there --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: -- in that -- that particular moment with reference to this venire?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: That was the petit jury venire.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: Well, what is that?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: There was a motion, I believe, at that time to quash the venire.
There was first a --

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: All the jurors --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: -- summoned for the week?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: All who had been summoned and qualified or had they been qualified at that --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: They had been qualified at that time, I believe.
Also, I should like to point out to the Court that there is no positive record as to who struck the two remaining Negro juries -- jurors.
As I point out, there were five jurors called.

One, I believe (Inaudible) was excused for being over 65, two were excused for -- one had an attack and one was sick, which he's permitted to -- for the trial juries in Alabama to excuse those men on noncapital cases.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: May I ask you just one other question --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- to clear my mind.
How many were on the total venire for the week to try cases?
How many jurors?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: From the discussion of the case, sir, only five names are mentioned.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: Only what?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Five Negroes are mentioned.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: I mean --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Oh, the entire, I believe they are 68, sir.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: 68 people.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: Now, when the time came to strike, was there right given to strike from the entire 68 or was there a certain group brought into the courtroom?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: There was a hearing which they excuse some young and then they were strict on -- in accordance with Alabama law of which the State has one strike and the defendant has two.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: From the entire venire?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: I asked that because it used to be the practice in some of the counties that you would call for a certain number of jurors out of the entire venire.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes.
Well, this --

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: They would be called into the courtroom and would strike from that --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: This was the entire venire.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: -- number which was left in the total venire.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.
This was that case there.
That --

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: This case?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: -- this was 68.
Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: The whole 68?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.
They were called less --

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: Passed the --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: -- those who had been excused.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: Passed the question and they granted certain excuses.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: And then they were allowed to strike.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: Plaintiff getting one and the defendant, two.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes sir, that is in con for Alabama law and --

turn.speaker: mrjustice_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Stewart
turn.text: This in -- in each lawsuit that comes up the whole 68 less those who have been excused coming to the courtroom?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: This was -- venire was drawn for this particular case.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Stewart
turn.text: Well, I understood yesterday that it was on for the -- for the -- for this particular term of court.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: I believe that was a grand jury that was called for that particular time.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Stewart
turn.text: Now, I am mixed up.
There are 1800 or so on the -- on the permanent list of jurors.
Is that right?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir, that is correct.
Approximately --

turn.speaker: mrjustice_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Stewart
turn.text: And I -- we were told yesterday that there were two terms of court in this county.
Plus perhaps special term sometime.
And that for this term, I'd understood that this was the venire, these 68 people.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: This was a venire called for the petit jury --

turn.speaker: mrjustice_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Stewart
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: -- that actually tried the man in --

turn.speaker: mrjustice_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Stewart
turn.text: We're talking about --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: -- this particular --

turn.speaker: mrjustice_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Stewart
turn.text: -- the petit jury.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Stewart
turn.text: Only and only the petit jury.
For that term or for that case?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: It says for that week, drawn for that week, I believe.
A jury list criminal court February 23rd, 1959 term that was the exhibit.
And they drew the 12 men striking them, as I've said, for this term.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Stewart
turn.text: Well, now, when the case is called for trial, what happens?
How many people come into the jury box or come into the courtroom as perspective jurors?
12 or 68 or what?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: 68 less these who have been excused.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Stewart
turn.text: All of them coming into the court.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.
And they are --

turn.speaker: mrjustice_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Stewart
turn.text: And then --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: -- stricken.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Stewart
turn.text: Well, then, 12 of them come to the jury box and are then --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Stewart
turn.text: -- qualified for voir dire?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: -- 12 eventually are going to the jury box (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: mrjustice_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Stewart
turn.text: Eventually, well, what happens --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Well, they --

turn.speaker: mrjustice_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Stewart
turn.text: -- before they do?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Well, they strike them.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Stewart
turn.text: They strike them before they go into the jury box?
Do they have voir dire of all 68 of them?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: They -- they qualify first.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Stewart
turn.text: All 68 of them?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.
They qualify.
First, they grant excuses for the -- the ones who asked to be excused for various reasons, sir.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Stewart
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: And then they qualify them as to -- that came to the first and a thing of that nature that would disqualify them and then when they are down to the -- the rest of the jurors on there, then the -- the last step is for the State enter -- entered to strike the jury of the remaining people on this list.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: You strike it this way, do you not?As you left, you have paid them, 55 left after they excuse them.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: The one whose name appears at the top of the list is called around and they stated there, should they take him and the defendant is asked if he takes him.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: And that's the way you strike it and you may get a juror without exhausting your entire venire at all.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: That is possible, sir.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Stewart
turn.text: What the term is where -- where he is on the list, whether he's at the top of the list or is it alphabetical or what?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Well, sir, in -- in this case, it was not alphabetically.
They were just drawn --

turn.speaker: mrjustice_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Stewart
turn.text: Who determines who's at the top of the list?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: They're just drawn out of the hat and input the -- the names are put in down.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: You mean they are (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: That appears to be near that.
They're not alphabetically drawn in this case, sir, because here, we have (Inaudible).

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: The clerk picks up, prepares that list, does it not?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir, that is correct.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: Puts them in a certain order.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: We had a case called one time somewhere where the question was whether certain names had been put at the bottom purposely so that it'd be difficult to reach.
And there's no question I can't raise.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.

I believe it wasn't -- I believe that was Hill versus Texas where they had done that, if I'm not mistaken as to the name, but in that particular case, they had the first 12 white persons and after that, there were Negroes 13, 14, 15 and 16 and it was the custom of that community to draw the first way of the grand juries.
That did not exist in these things.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But is this drawing that you say the clerk makes to -- of this list done in -- by lot in public, in the trial or --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.
That was drawn in -- in the courtroom.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: It's done in the courtroom.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: In the courtroom, yes sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Probably drawn a -- the cards as I've said are white with no distinguishing marks as to color of the --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: You mean they're drawn before -- they're just drawn out of the box and then that -- these that are drawn are summoned.
Is that correct?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: That is correct, yes.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: It may be done a week or two weeks before they --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: -- their term.
They're drawn by the judge -- they are drawn by the judge still in the courtroom, are they?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: Open court.
And then they -- they give -- turned over to the sheriff and the order of clerk, in the order in which they are drawn, he draws up a list and they have summoned.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: That's correct, sir.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: And does the law require him to follow the -- that same order when he makes up his list from those who were found?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: I found no code section require in that.
I think it is use as a practice sir.
And I should like to point out to the Court there is no definite record as to who struck the remaining two Negroes on the jury list on page 62 of the record.
There was a little discussion there in open court, I believe, when Mr. McCloud and Attorney Billingsley.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What you names are Negroes on this list, do you recall Mr. Clark?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.
I do not, sir.
No, sir.(Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That's alright.
Just go ahead.
I suppose it's --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: I think one of them was Benny Phillips.
I don't recall the other nature, but he was one of the two.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Go ahead.
Don't take your time for that.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: I should like further to point out that the question of when a Negro had registered on the grand jury was in 1954 or rather than 1953.
I think this is important to call to the attention of the Court for this reason.
There had been a new jury roll in October of 1953.
If we go on premise that the -- this bureau was in 1953, he would've been on the old role and he found a new one actually.
He was called in January of 1954, according to the testimony of one Gerald Hicks (ph) on page 45.
Now, there was a flat statement named at the present time.
There were 1800 jurors on the jury roll and of this number one in every 12, were Negroes.

I'd like to point out to the Court that on page -- record page 34 wherein Mr. Glen H. Depke, the Jury Commissioner and the chairman of it, about two-thirds down the page, "Can you tell the court," excuse me -- "How many names are on the jury list in Dallas County altogether?"
"I never count it.
I don't know."
"Do you have any judgment of the number of those names who are Negroes?"
"Well, I don't know all of them that are registered.
I don't know all the whites or non-whites, but I guess 1 in 12 would be none white."
"Yes."
"Would you care to give us some estimate of the total number of jurors on the register?"
"I would guess somewhere around 1800.

That is -- points that I had strictly and yes he does know the exact number on that and the reason I want to point that out to the Court is that the jury rolls were never requested to be presented in the Court as on the hearing of this motion as they were in Norris versus Alabama."

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: If they had -- if they had --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: The exact number could've been found.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But they have told how many Negroes and how many whites were from -- from the names --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Not from the names themselves.
They'd have to know it from personal observation of --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Wouldn't be -- wouldn't do much good on this?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: They would not do if it gives the exact number.
That's all it would de novo people on the jury roll.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Those are all the correct entitled.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Make any statement made by Mr.Greenberg.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Now, the petitioner in his brief has cited in number of cases using short excerpts from them and stating or inferring that the procedure in this case now before the Court, is quite similar to these cases he'd cites.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_harlan
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Harlan
turn.text: Could I ask you a question?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_harlan
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Harlan
turn.text: Starting from the premise of the 1953, it's made up in the jury as the Government 300 Negro men (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_harlan
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Harlan
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Well, it was out of 1500 at that time, sir.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_harlan
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Harlan
turn.text: 1500 at that time.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_harlan
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Harlan
turn.text: Alright.
That's one problem.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_harlan
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Harlan
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: May it please the Court.
On that, I would like to point out this Mr.Glen H.Depke who was appointed chairman of the Jury Commission in 1954.
And on -- this was his first appearance in court, perhaps he was flustered.
He says, "I guess they are now 1500 or 1800 names on the jury roll and I guess that 1 out of 12 is non-white."
He didn't know the exact number.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: May I ask you sir?
Once a name gets in that what I call a wheel --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: -- that's what it was in the jurisdiction I practiced.
How did it ever get out of there?
I mean of course, I know you draw them but aren't to put back after they asserted?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes sir, they are.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Well, if there were -- if there were certain number of whites and certain number of Negroes in originally, unless they died, how do they get out?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Well, if they die or move away from that locality, they could pull their names out.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: How would one tell?
If I went down there today and look at those cards, how would I tell how many were white and how many were Negroes?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: You couldn't and I don't believe I could either that there is no identification on the card itself.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Was there any other identification, any other record, showing?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Well a county record would probably -- the birth record would show whether person was white or colored.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Or something of that nature, but as far as the intermediate records are concerned, there is nothing that would identify him as to race.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_harlan
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Harlan
turn.text: What would -- what would be this basis for Mr. Depke's statement?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Just a guess beyond that, that's the only thing I can (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: mrjustice_harlan
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Harlan
turn.text: He says 1 in 12.
He didn't --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: He was just grabbing one of the air and saying that that's 1 in 12.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: If a juror who -- whose name is in this wheel, moves away, how does the Jury Commissioners know about that or assume they find out in some way, do they then go and take his name out of the wheel?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.
They -- they authorize it.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: They do.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.
And then the court said and you name that from time to time.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: And you point to anything in the record which would neutralize or offset or refuse the statement whether it was a guess, an informed guess or what it was that was made of that they're being 1 in 12.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.
That was just said statement --

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: But we were --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: -- and that's the only thing we have in the record.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: We should assume I suppose that -- that we're not the fact, the State and its officials, would have accident, would we not?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: If they knew come in (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: Is there anyway --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: But It would have been -- it is an incumbent on the defendant in that case to have called for the jury roll if he want to show anything that he want to point out if he -- he knew that any had been excluded or he knew him by name or race.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: The gentleman who testified here, what position?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: He was chairman of the Jury Commission of Dallas County.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: Is it his duty to keep informed as to what names are there and who's there?
Is it -- is that a part of his responsibility?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: These are all responsibility, I would say, but the clerk keeps the actual names --

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: Did he even keep the accurate names with its -- it's the duty of the Jury Commission isn't it to give the name finally and select to find (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: To find people but --

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: And I would assume that in Dallas County, the Jury Commissioner would have a pretty good knowledge or we can assume he can --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: He sure had the knowledge --

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: -- whether they were white or colored.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.
He should have a knowledge.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: And how can -- how can we decide this case on any basis except that this uncontradicted statement of his is correct whether -- whatever result it leads to is different.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: I may have pointed out that he had said that was the guess.
It -- it maybe -- that or now 1 in 10 or I don't know.
That it was his estimate and he kept saying it was a guess.
He didn't give up a definite statement to that -- there are so many --

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: Well, I -- I suppose there's nobody and maybe not even the clerk perhaps who should be and better informed on that than the Jury Commissioner is he?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Probably not, sir.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: Of course that's their sole responsibility, isn't it?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.
That was their --

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: They have no other jobs, are these men, do they hold any other public job in Dallas County?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: That's that --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: They do not.
He was a retired army captain.
I believe they refer to him as Captain Death.
As I would -- said the petitioner cited in a number of cases and was using little excerpts from these cases in writing his excellent brief, in checking over these cases he cited.
However, I find that they are not exactly like in facts so that they would be as we say on all force with this case, for instance, Avery versus Georgia.
That decision rested on the ground that the use of the jury courts of white and yellow to -- to note the race that constituted prima facie evidence of discrimination.
I believe as this Court pointed out the box from which these cards were taken had an opening large enough for the judge to look in and see whether that was a white or yellow card.
We don't have anything like this in the present case.
The judge reached in, pulled out a name, the all name sort of just written on the cards, similar cards, no difference of cards.
Now, the other case cited was Cassell versus Texas.

That was a case where the Jury Commissioners went off on the idea following as they interpreted Akins versus Texas to mean that as long as they had one Negro on the jury that that satisfied the requirement for such discrimination -- that limitation of course, in violation.
We don't have this in -- in the present case.

Now, in Eubanks versus Louisiana, another case which was cited, this Court held that while the Jury Commissioners selected 75 names impartially, that the trial judge picked his grand jury from people he knew personally and had personal knowledge of their race and therefore, this was discrimination.
Hernandez versus Texas, that the Court after saying that the petition met the burden of proof is set out in Norris versus Alabama and said that the State has not rebutted this prima facie case.
In -- in that one, it seemed that the Jury Commissioners just left out all names that denoted Mexican or Spanish descent.
Now, Hill versus Texas is another one.
The Court held that the -- a prima facie case was ade out and the State bail needed.

And Negroes were omitted from the grand jury list for 16 years or more in spite of the fact that various names had been mentioned to them and they just failed to carry out their duties to investigate any of these people.
This wasn't the case here.
We had evidence, Mr.Depke that he had gone out in various parts of the county and going to stores and meeting places and -- and ask about people.
I would like to point out at this time that Dallas County is a rural community.
And your best source of information is usually a country grocery store in which you go and buy a soft drink and talk with the owner and he can tell you about everybody in that vicinity.
Now, there was something said in the testimony about if he didn't know any particular Negroes in that area.

He asked some good white men, that may seem as -- that was discrimination, but in this area of the State, most of the stores are run by white men, the grocery stores or country gentle merchandise stores and he probably has went and asked some questions.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: May I ask you just a few --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: -- statistics, of course you realize whatever these cases say as you've said, we've got to consider this case somewhat on those facts.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.
I'm just pointing out there was not on all force, are not very similarly.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: That is -- that's -- that's correct.
What is the -- the total voting population of Dallas County now?
Do you know?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.
Frankly, I -- I don't --

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: The record doesn't show.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: The record doesn't --

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: What is the total -- you wouldn't know --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Now, it did show the -- the number of Negro and whites over 21 males, I believe it was 6940 white males and 7438 Negro males to over 21.
Now, it's gone in 1950 Census.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: What is the --
What are the literacy figures in Dallas County now, with reference to those over 21, do you know?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.
But I -- I believe Mr. Greenberg cited it and I think he said in generally, the whites had a seventh grade education and colored people, approximately non-whites, about fourth grade education.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: You have schools for both, there now?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.
We do.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: Scattered pretty well over the county?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir, they are.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: And you still have compulsory education for both groups?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.
Page 16 --

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: Which is -- which is the law in Dallas County.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.
That is in full sentence.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: Is this -- do you know how the illiterates of that compares in Dallas as to both races were the literacy or illiteracy in the other counties in the State.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: It's rather low that they didn't see that, I think we compared with the other places.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: The literacy?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.
They don't go as far in schools as they do in some of the more populated counties.
This is a farming area.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: Is that it?
Is there any difference in the number so appreciable difference, total illiteracy.
That is that people can't read and write.
Do you have that between --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir, I don't have that (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: Well, that's not a notice -- I -- I wouldn't think that's a noticeable percentages of people in Dallas now, who couldn't read or write.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: I don't know the exact number, but I think they are deaf in minority.
They cannot read or write without brief in education.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is there any literacy test for jurors in that county?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: I believe they must read and write except that they are free holders or householders and that is the waived in that case.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.
So there is no literacy test?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: With those two exceptions, I just named there would be.
They have to be able to read and write, unless they are free holders or householders.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Everybody?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Everyone, yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Unless they are free holders or householders.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: In that event, they do not have to be -- they do not have to follow any literacy test.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.
Now, I was wondering -- I'm wondering this.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- in these other cases that you have been talking about, if they have the same requirements for -- for drawing up the -- the jury panel that you have here, as I -- as I read it, the Jury Commission shall make in a well bound book roll containing the name of every male citizen living in the county who possessed the qualifications herein described.

The Jury Commission shall place on the jury roll and in the jury box the names of all male citizens of the county who are generally refuted to be honest and intelligent and are esteemed in the community for their integrity, good character and sound judgment.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now, as I understand it, they -- the Jury Commissioner only found 1800 --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: That is current.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- in this county who had fulfilled that requirement, both white and black.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But he is under the law, required to put all of them in there who have that character.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Please the Court.
I cited in my brief the case of Wimbush versus State which is the Alabama case, 237 Ala.153.

Said the purpose of the statute providing no objection may be taken any venire jurors set to fraud in draw and summon the jurors, is to prevent quashing a venire if I may, irregularities and to obviate result and delays.

Well, in that, there was citing that Section 46 in which you just read and it was stated there that unless there was fraud in drawing or sounding the jurors that a motion to quash would not lie in that case.
Therefore that we have the Alabama condition determination that it doesn't require every --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But it does not require.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: It does not require -- and that is of course, that case was 1939 and that came after that Attorney General's opinion cited by the petitioner in his brief.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: May I ask you now with reference to this.
What I'm sure you have realized is the crucial point in the case to Justice Harlan.
Assuming that it is correct that the percentage has dropped from --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: -- from 1 in 5 to 1 in 12, is there any reasonable explanation that could be made on that from the record?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.
The record doesn't show any -- any reason for that.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: There's certainly no --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: There --

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: -- no less literacy among the --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: One group, the colored group that they were on, is any reason to assume that not just as many or more people of good character and reputation than they were before?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: May it please the Court in that -- that invades the discretionary power.

The Jury Commissioner it says that they shall go out and -- and check on these people and as the requirements so that each jurors must be honest and intelligent and have their reputation for integrity and good character and sound judgment in that community.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: But I have --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: So they have some discretion in that, it would -- it does follow that because every white person, when he became 21, he would not of itself, be a prospective juror that would not -- the qualification of a Negro.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: That is correct.
But I was asking on the -- with the idea that you had not only the state law but you have the federal law, which says there must be no discrimination on account of color.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: And what -- what reason can you think of except color to account for this decided drop in the -- percentages realizing of course, you do not have to have a special percentage.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: What reason can you advance in the practice in Alabama or what has occurred reference to filling the boxes or anything else, it could be responsible for that, except color.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, the one thing I could think of, just off hand is that the Jury Commissioners put more names of whites than they did of the Negro race.
Now, whether --

turn.speaker: mrjustice_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Stewart
turn.text: The record suggests -- the record suggests, one reason, don't it, the one reason that you relied on the court below, the -- that the fact that arrests in the county, 85% of those arrested in the county where non-whites and that suggest that --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: That (Voice Overlap) that goes along with the discretionary power of the Jury Commissioners to -- to lay it.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: When you say discretionary power, that implies that the discretion was exercised on something or on, hasn't it?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, what I want to know is on what was what you call the discretion exercise.
That Commissioners -- the jury -- the jury selectors didn't examine each one of the potential jurors, white and color, did they?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, they are the one who counted.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: How many -- on the basis of how many was the selection made if you straighten me out?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: I believe there were approximately 14,000 of both white and --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, not --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: -- Negro race.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- with reference to the selection of this jury.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Oh, no, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: On the basis -- how many -- on the basis of how many in exact number was the selection of the 12 here made?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: The ones -- well, there were 68 to start with, some were excused, I would --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: -- say around --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: -- 40 people were left to be struck and there were two missing.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But from the 68, how many, to start with, were white as against colored or colored as against white?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Well, it was definitely shown that there were five Negroes --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, those five --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Those are the ones not found.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Those -- those five were drawn out of how many?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: 5 out of 68.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: No, no.
I don't mean of the total.
Out of those five Negroes were drawn out of a total pool of how many Negroes?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Well, if we follow Mr.Depke's guess that would be out of 150.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now did he make a custody exercise of personal judgment as to each one of the 150 or did he go as you suggested the local -- the general store, the grocery and talk with him?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Well, he said he, in his testimony, said he went to various people and talk with them.He talked to some prospective jurors.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But do we know whether he selected the five act of personal inspection, of personal examination of inquiry of each of the 150 face-to-face, probably not?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: I believe from his testimony, he did not.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: He did not.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: He did not.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Therefore, what you call an exercise of discretion was based on some -- was derived from a basis other than his own determination when he saw John Smith that John Smith would not be a good perspective juror, isn't that right?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.
Well, the statute says about the reputation in --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well I'm not -- I'm not questioning it.
I just want to know what the basis of the choice what you call in answer to Justice Black's question.
He exercised discretion --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- when we have this drop which raises questions of how did it come about.
It might come about because in a particular year, in a particular era, in a particular county, there may have been only two personal inspections five whom in his judgment would qualify.
But that isn't the situation we had.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So that he relied on somebody else or somebody else's --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Well, there are three Jury Commissioners.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: There are three Jury Commissioners in that case that may have been --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Whether three of them -- whether three of them.
The three of them relied not on the personal examination and judgment upon the individual 150, but some secondary source.
Is that right?
I don't mean by secondary to --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: I realize what you mean now.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- to derogate from the force.
All I'm trying to search --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: From his statement, he said that he interviewed some persons and some just their reputation as we might say hearsay.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But you couldn't or -- or could you, unless the record shows it, you couldn't, there was a record, say that he did a sampling on the basis of which he rejected 104 -- on the basis of which the juror commissioners rejected 145.
That's what this gets down to, doesn't it?
Isn't that right?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.
There were 150 in the jury roll and I believe they were -- they were just a name for taken out by the jury.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But I thought you've said the -- I asked you in this --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Oh, I -- I am -- I must --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- the five Negroes were out of a potential body of how many Negroes?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Approximately 150.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, that's what I say.
So 145 were rejected through sampling of the 150 of the -- through sampling, isn't that true?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir, because that the -- there was a jury roll of approximately 1800 and just -- so they were -- the names were picked out.
They were -- the -- there were no five Negroes picked out.
It was just five --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Were the 150 put into the box to be picked out from?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: As Mr. Depke said there were approximately 150 and colored --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Colored, names and by chance, they just picked five and yet out of the white names, they picked X out of Y, whatever it is?

turn.speaker: mrjustice_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Stewart
turn.text: The same percentage, the approximate thing?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: --percentage, I believe.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So this -- so that the -- the selection you say was based on -- on chance, on the -- on the (Voice Overlap) on the impersonalness and the disinterestedness of chance.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: That is correct, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well then, where -- where did the -- where did the discretion come in?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Well, the discretion is that when the Jury Commission goes out into the district and they ask about one of the names they have, say, it's John Jones --

turn.speaker: mrjustice_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Stewart
turn.text: Making up the list of 1800 (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, making up the list or adding to the list.
Then --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well -- well that I so understood in evident added and put my questions correctly.
In making up the list --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- you rejected or the Commissioners rejected how many out of how many?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: I don't have those facts.
I don't believe they were brought out at the trial.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But is that important if -- if out of a potential body of jurors, how many -- only an -- an unfair ratio that from the colored jurors was left as against the whites and if it occurs regularly, then I'd like to know where discretion played its part?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Well, when the Jury Commission goes out to interview perspective jurors, if -- if the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Even -- even the way which you indicate by going to the grocery stores of the (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Well, I -- I just said in the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- or the local teacher or doctor or whatnot.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Teacher, doctor in one community, sir.
If they say well that's a good person, he's had maybe a few driving offenses or -- or perhaps he was -- gets drunk occasionally, which is possibility, it did.
And that happens quite seldom and otherwise, he's a person of good character and either white or Negro that they could put him in the service --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes, but there's a disproportion --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: In a roll.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- there's a disproportion in the result of this process, isn't there so far as numbers go?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir, there is.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And that's the problem that would come before us.

Whether this -- this proportion is the product of -- of fair judgment on relevant materials or is a product of the chances of life, the contingencies of life or whether it is a product of starting out to say we're not going to have more than X number of Negroes.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Nowhere in the testimony was there anything brought out as to we picked on -- on this jury, five Negroes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, there was nothing like that either in the Cassell case that the reference has been made to that.

And for myself, if something operates discriminatorily, uniformly, then there's -- then it isn't the operation of either chance or -- or discretion based on relevant criteria because the dice don't always fall seven-eleven --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: That's correct, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- not even for the (Voice Overlap) draw.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Isn't that true?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: That is true, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And how do you account for this discrepancy?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: As I have said, the only way I could is that the Jury Commission only put on a -- a certain number of white and colored names with those that they interviewed or checked into and it -- suppose in this case, there are more whites than colored.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What you're saying -- are you saying that the juror of the Commission going around and making an honest effort to find out according to his life who was serviceable jurors, I mean --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- one function of being a juror, he went through the grocery store and he went to the local doctor and he went to the teacher and whatnot.
And they said, there is Jones and there is Smith and there is Robinson.
And -- and apparently, those are the only ones his recommenders could give him, is that it?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Well, he goes out with the names already and -- and checks his names out.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But the potentialities, yes.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And they say, well I wouldn't have him.
I wouldn't have him.
And you say it's the result of that kind of as saying the people under, there's tool --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- the judgment of his advisers, his own knowledge (Inaudible) jury.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's your position.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: And I believe this Court has held its burden is on the petitioner and instance like that the defendant to -- to show there has been some discrimination.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Let me ask you this question, Mr. Clark.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: These are perhaps broad questions.
Has the Attorney General of Alabama any relation to the jury selecting process?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir, we don't (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Who -- when do they derive their standards for selecting jurors?
I know the statute is there.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes sir, on the statutes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes.
But who tells them, who is it?
Is it the local judge?

Could the Attorney General send out a general letter of instructions or advice or information saying, "We have carefully studied the decisions of the Supreme Court of United States which are ultimately governing to this matter and we would like to enumerate what it is that you can come in compliance with those decisions in the light of the statute," because there's no suggestion here, but the statute as such, is there -- is unconstitutional?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir, there's nothing --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Discrimination isn't written on the face of the statute.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.
Not on the statute.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Alright.
Therefore, it's a question of the tools that were given to them, namely, the statute how they should use those tools.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes.

I will point out that while the Attorney General could do that, I should also point out that any member of the Jury Commission could write to the Attorney General upon opinion of how he (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Had there been any such general instruction by anybody either the Attorney General's Office or the Court to which the Jury Commissioners were attached in whatever way they are attached?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.
I don't believe so.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So that every Jury Commissioner is guided by his own life or what he's heard, what these decisions are.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Suppose you were coming back from this argument, suppose you were Attorney General or you could -- could be your chief, suppose there were such a letter of instruction or -- or recommendation, could you as you stand there, formulate what you conceive to be the duties of Jury Commissioner in the light of our decision, what would you tell them?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: I think in the light of the juror -- of this Court decision, there should be no discrimination.
I believe you have frequently held that.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I know, but they -- nobody suggested that they consciously discriminated in this case, do they?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So it's the operation of a system on misconception of what -- how that system is to work.
That's what he gets down to, isn't it?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes sir, the exercise in the legislation.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And people might as honest as days long or more honest than a 24-hour day.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And yet misconceive what it is that their duty is.
That's -- that's the real problem and that this problem, isn't it?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes.

Yes, sir, and I would like to point out that Mr.Depke in his testimony as to his immediate precinct pointed out that there were seven members on the jury roll -- jurors, four were Negroes and three were whites.
That was in his own precinct, sir.
So --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That -- what kind of a population -- how large a population would that cover?
Can you make a guess on that?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Very small to that there were only seven jurors in there, possibly 100 people this precinct is.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What you said, said seven Negroes and three whites?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: I mean they were seven jurors.
There were four Negroes and three whites.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Three whites.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: What precinct was that?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Martin Station was the name given to that.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: What's the division of population to that precinct?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: I don't have --

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: Three whites and blacks.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: I do not know that, sir, but based on the county population that if we go along the 1950 census, it would be about half and half of --

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: What, in that precinct?
I'm talking about that precinct?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Martin Station?

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: I assume it's approximate that sir, but I do not know, I don't have any (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Have you -- have your counties --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, we have.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Have your counties in which the county's almost completely Negro -- Negro population?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir, they are.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Are there any --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Approximately three counties in the State.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: Pardon me?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Approximately three counties.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: Three counties.
Have we got any data in this record or any judicial notice or statistical census reports as to what the situation is in those counties?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.
That wasn't brought out at the trial.
I believe those counties are Lowndes, Marengo and Tuskegee.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: You have precinct in Dallas County, do you not, where the same kind of disproportion exist (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, I have some.

Now, in another case, it was cited on Neal versus Delaware, we definitely have the statute there that excluded persons that have been dissent from jury service, but of course that ever gone this face was -- this different from this one that we have here and another one cited was Pierre versus Louisiana.
And this was one where there were approximately one-half the population was Negro.
And that no Negro had said it was petit or grand jury in the last 10 years.

Now, in anytime on the grand jury and they had 300 names in the venire box, three of these were Negroes, one was a dead person, dead Negroes, so there were really only two out of 299, and they held this was discrimination.
Well, that -- that's a long way from the case we have before the Court.
The only similarity there is that there were approximately half of the population was Negro.

In the Reese versus Georgia, another case cited, we -- that was a due process matter in which the Georgia rule of practice required the defendant to challenge the composition of the grand jury before the indictment, where the grand jury was empanelled, sworn in eight days before the man was indicted in that case and he did not have counsel appointed until the day after he was indicted.Of course, that was due process.
It was violated there.
That's nowhere near the case before the Court.
Shepherd versus Florida, we had discrimination there.
Negroes were discriminated against on the jury system.
And there was also the possible race rot and things of that nature, newspaper writings that just prevented a fair trial to the man so that was questioned in.

Smith versus Texas was the other one that -- where they drew a grand jury in which they put the first way of names, white people and then 13, 14, 15, 16 were of the Negro race and there was a local practice to pick the first 12.
And that was just a stag deck, so to speak, there.

Of course, Estrada versus West Virginia is the one that said that all white male through 21 years and a citizen of this States shall be liable to serve as jurors except this hearing provided and they provided for certain state officials.
Of course, that excluded all persons of Negro descent.
But once again, that's a long ways from the case we have before the Court.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: I'd like to ask one more --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: -- just to get it clear, I hate to ask you so many questions.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: Does the record show whether the box has been emptied (Inaudible) in anyway --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: --up to the time when there were a bigger percentage of colored people.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: That did -- there was a showing that in 1953, October 1953, the box was pushed of all means and then a new disc was made up.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: Completely refilled.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Completely refilled.
That was the time that 1500 were put in.
Now --

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: Now -- now, after what I'm getting at is, what does it show has happened since then with reference to the box?
Had there been supplements to put in?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, there had been additional names and the deletion of certain names, people who died (Inaudible).

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: Well, has there -- had there been one or two times when they put in a large number according to the record?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: The record didn't show of any.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: Has there been one or two times whether -- when they took out a large number according to the record?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: The record did not show that once again.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: It doesn't show it either way?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: The defendant did not ask that question.
I did not endeavor to bring that out in any fashion.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: They stood on the results rather than --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: They stood on the ground that there were 1800 jurors.
There were only approximately 150 Negroes.
Now, the petitioner in his brief on page 14 says that petitioner does not challenge the system of selecting jurors as such in Alabama.
He points that out on himself.
In fact, he points out several things in the -- it just is undecided of what he had based in his claim that there was discrimination at the trial.
It was pointed out and the Court asked the attorney for the present petition.
Did he have any objection to the way the jury was known and he said, "No, except for the names -- discrepancy that the pro -- pro rata share of names being just a small portion of Negroes."

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Do you know if whether or not, there was any practice in that section of the State where Negro defendants not to want, but to strike Negro jurors in criminal cases.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir, I would point out though that as to who struck and who stood to gain by the striking up and there was no showing that had these two Negroes been left on the jury that the case would have changed one way or the other.
On the other hand, as they were struck, that's the reason the petitioners up here claiming there was discrimination.
So if there was anybody to profit by the striking, it -- it would be to presume that it was the petitioner.
He had two chances against one of the State to strike him.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: Well, are you arguing that they struck him?
I don't know that that have --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: The record does not show.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: It's possible that they did.
If they -- if they did, then they created their own petition of here, the ground for it.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: I would suppose

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.
The record does not show.
I've pointed that out by record at page 62.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_harlan
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Harlan
turn.text: Would there be minutes that even or not in the record is reflecting that back in your court?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: No, sir.
I don't have knowledge of such.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Well your examination is ordinarily not transcribed?

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: They were not in this case.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: There'd be no difficulty to find out where difficult -- everybody knows who struck the -- find out in five minutes.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, so they -- they could have it if they want to present it.
That's another thing I want to point out that the petitioner could have brought that up who struck them.
He could have made that a point on his appeal.
He did not choose to do that.
He did not choose to ask for the jury roll to be brought out in court, to show if there were at the last minute as in Norris versus Alabama, some names handwritten on the roll.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_harlan
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Harlan
turn.text: Perhaps they can supply that to his knowledge and rebut.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: That still, the Court was not answering the charge that they have made.
I'm not sure that it would be relevant.
What they're saying is that regardless of the fact he did -- that normally you had it on --

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: -- shows in itself that couldn't have been, using Justice Frankfurter's statements, of pure chance.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: It could have been.

turn.speaker: mrjustice_black
turn.label: Mr. Mr.justice Black
turn.text: I'd say that -- that's the argument.

turn.speaker: david_w_clark
turn.label: Mr. David W. Clark
turn.text: Yes, sir (Voice Overlap).
Now, I'd like to point out to one or two more recent cases.

One is Speller versus Allen, in which in Vance County, North Carolina, there were 145 names out of a total of 2126 names in the jury box, and this Court held that that was no evidence of discrimination in that case.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
